questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.
  • • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:
  • • Mild: 10-10.9 g% Moderate: 7-9 g% Severe: <7 g%
  • • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • • Severe: <7 g%
  • • Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia
  • • Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia
  • • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron. Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • • Mild anemia or moderate anemia:
  • • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron:
  • • Treating Severe Anemia
  • • Treating Severe Anemia
  • • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose. Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.
  • • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • • Hemoglobin < 7 g%:
  • • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.
  • • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 10 to 12 weeks : While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.
  • • Option A. 10 to 12 weeks
  • • Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.
  • • Option C. After 14 weeks:
  • • Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.
  • • Option D. After 20 weeks:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension that began earlier in the day. His parents report that he has had similar episodes of abdominal pain and constipation intermittently over the past few months. On examination, his abdomen is markedly distended and tender, particularly in the lower quadrants. Imaging studies suggest a bowel obstruction. During emergency surgery, the surgeon discovers a segment of necrotic small bowel due to a volvulus. What is the most appropriate method for performing the anastomosis after resection of the necrotic bowel?

options.label: D
options.text: Simple continuous suture with absorbable material

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • The single-layer extramucosal suture technique, also known as the Halsted technique, involves placing sutures in the seromuscular layer of the bowel without penetrating the mucosa. This method reduces operative time, minimizes trauma to the bowel, and lowers the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leaks. It is particularly effective in small bowel anastomosis, especially in cases involving compromised bowel tissue, as it enhances healing while maintaining the integrity of the bowel wall.
  • • The extramucosal approach is favored in compromised or necrotic bowel conditions because it preserves the bowel’s structural integrity while promoting optimal healing with reduced complications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Traditional double-layer suture technique: This option is incorrect because the traditional two-layer technique involves suturing both the mucosal and seromuscular layers, which can increase operative time and risk of complications, particularly in fragile or necrotic bowel segments due to excessive tissue handling.
  • • Option B. Traditional double-layer suture technique:
  • • Option C. Interrupted sutures with delayed re-evaluation: This option is incorrect because delaying the decision for a complete anastomosis is not advisable when viable tissue is available for primary anastomosis. Immediate, appropriate anastomotic technique should be used to prevent further complications.
  • • Option C. Interrupted sutures with delayed re-evaluation:
  • • Option D. Simple continuous suture with absorbable material: This option is incorrect as the simple continuous suture does not specifically target the needs of compromised bowel, and it can increase the risk of anastomotic failure compared to the controlled placement of the single-layer extramucosal suture.
  • • Option D. Simple continuous suture with absorbable material:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method for bowel anastomosis in cases involving necrotic or compromised bowel tissue. This approach minimizes surgical trauma, reduces the risk of postoperative complications, and supports optimal healing, making it a critical choice in managing complex bowel conditions encountered during surgery.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) QALY

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels. This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.
  • ➤ Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • ➤ This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? ( NEET PG 2020)

Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Pain in the calf while walking

options.label: B
options.text: Pain in the buttocks while walking

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain in the buttocks while walking
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pain in the buttocks while walking

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most frequent symptom of aortoiliac disease is gluteal claudication, which is characterized by pain in the buttocks during walking. This pain occurs due to the location of the blockage in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to reduced blood flow to the buttocks, hips, and thighs.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A . Pain in the calf while walking: This is typically associated with femoropopliteal disease rather than aortoiliac occlusive disease.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Pain in the calf while walking:
  • • Option C . Erectile dysfunction: Although impotence can occur in Leriche syndrome, which involves aortoiliac occlusive disease, it is not the most common symptom.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Erectile dysfunction:
  • • Option D . No symptoms at all: While some individuals may be asymptomatic, the most common presentation includes symptoms like gluteal claudication in the case of aortoiliac disease.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • No symptoms at all:
  • • Educational objectives :
  • • Educational objectives :
  • • The primary symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease is pain in the buttocks while walking, known as gluteal claudication

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron

options.label: C
options.text: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool

options.label: D
options.text: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.correct_answer: A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.
  • • Reason for decerebrate rigidity:
  • • Reason for decerebrate rigidity:
  • • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent. From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity. Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.
  • • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.
  • • Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by
  • • γ motor neuron discharge rate increased. Motor neuron pool excitability increased. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury
  • • γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  • • Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  • • Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  • • Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron : Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.
  • • Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
  • • Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool : Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.
  • • Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
  • • Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock : Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.
  • • Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes and underwent treatment for the same. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How will you follow up the patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: B
options.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.
  • ➤ Mammography is the only imaging modality required for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. Tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan currently have no role in follow-up.
  • ➤ Guidelines for follow-up:
  • ➤ Guidelines for follow-up:
  • ➤ Physical examination:
  • ➤ Physical examination:
  • ➤ For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months After 5 years: Annually
  • ➤ For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • ➤ For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months
  • ➤ After 5 years: Annually
  • ➤ Mammography:
  • ➤ Mammography:
  • ➤ Initially, 6 months after surgery Thereafter, annually.
  • ➤ Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • ➤ Thereafter, annually.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a slowly enlarging, reddish nodule on her left thigh that she first noticed about six months ago. The lesion has been painless and stable in size, causing her no discomfort. Physical examination reveals a firm, well-defined, non-tender reddish nodule. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination is shown in the images provided. Based on the clinical presentation and histological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • A hemangioma is a benign tumor that results from an abnormal proliferation of blood vessels. Histopathologically, hemangiomas are well-circumscribed lesions composed of thin-walled, dilated blood vessels. The vessels are lined with flattened, uniform endothelial cells with minimal mitotic activity, indicating a benign nature. The vessels are often organized into lobules, separated by stromal cells such as fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and pericytes. In cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels appear larger and more dilated compared to the smaller vessels seen in capillary hemangiomas. These histological features help distinguish hemangiomas from other vascular and soft tissue tumors.
  • • Histopathological Features : Hemangiomas display lobules of dilated vessels, a well-circumscribed appearance, and uniform endothelial cells, confirming their benign vascular nature and differentiating them from other similar lesions.
  • • Histopathological Features
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pyogenic granuloma: This option is incorrect because pyogenic granulomas are rapidly growing, friable lesions that often bleed easily. Histologically, they show a proliferation of capillary-sized vessels within an edematous stroma, which is distinct from the more organized lobular vascular structure of a hemangioma.
  • • Option B. Pyogenic granuloma:
  • • Option C. Glomus tumor: This option is incorrect because glomus tumors typically present as painful nodules under the fingernails or other subungual locations. Histology shows nests of glomus cells surrounding blood vessels, differing significantly from the purely vascular structure seen in hemangiomas.
  • • Option C. Glomus tumor:
  • • Option D. Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP): This option is incorrect because DFSP typically presents as a firm, flesh-colored to reddish nodule with a slow but invasive growth pattern. Histologically, it shows a storiform pattern of spindle cells, unlike the well-circumscribed vascular appearance of hemangiomas.
  • • Option D. Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors characterized by well-circumscribed lesions composed of lobules of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels lined with uniform endothelial cells. Recognizing these histopathological features is essential for differentiating hemangiomas from other vascular lesions and guiding appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021) Infertility Dysmenorrhea Vaginal discharge Vaginal bleeding
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:
  • • 1. Infertility : Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.
  • • 1. Infertility
  • • 2. Dysmenorrhea : Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.
  • • 2. Dysmenorrhea
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. 3, 4 : Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.
  • • Option A. 3, 4
  • • Option B. 2, 3 : While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.
  • • Option B. 2, 3
  • • Option D. 2, 4 : Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.
  • • Option D. 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.correct_answer: D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands. It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • ➤ It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

  • ➤ Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. To enhance visualization of the gallbladder and reduce the risk of aspiration during the procedure, the patient is positioned as shown in the image. This position is often used in upper abdominal surgeries to facilitate better access to the surgical field. What is the name of the patient position depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • The image illustrates the Reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient’s head is elevated 15-30 degrees above the feet. This positioning is particularly beneficial during upper abdominal surgeries as it allows abdominal organs to move downward, away from the diaphragm, improving access to the surgical site. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the Reverse Trendelenburg position, sometimes combined with a slight left tilt, aids in exposing the gallbladder by retracting its fundus towards the diaphragm. This orientation not only enhances the surgical view but also minimizes the risk of aspiration during anesthesia. Restraints and sideboards are often used to prevent the patient from sliding off the table, ensuring safety during the procedure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Trendelenburg: This option is incorrect because the Trendelenburg position tilts the patient with the head down and feet elevated, increasing venous return and often used in shock or to improve access to the lower abdomen and pelvis, but it compromises exposure of the upper abdominal organs.
  • • Option B. Trendelenburg:
  • • Option C. Fowler’s: This option is incorrect because Fowler’s position involves a semi-sitting posture with the back elevated. It is primarily used for patients with respiratory distress or during recovery, and does not specifically improve access to the upper abdomen during surgery.
  • • Option C. Fowler’s:
  • • Option D. Supine: This option is incorrect because the supine position involves the patient lying flat on the back without any elevation of the head or feet. It does not provide the enhanced visualization or access required for upper abdominal surgeries like cholecystectomy.
  • • Option D. Supine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The Reverse Trendelenburg position is widely used in upper abdominal surgeries, such as laparoscopic cholecystectomy, to improve surgical exposure by shifting the abdominal organs downward, away from the diaphragm. This positioning facilitates better access to the surgical field and reduces the risk of aspiration, making it essential for optimizing patient safety and surgical outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically seen in MEN-1 syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior pituitary tumors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • MEN type 1 (MEN 1), also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Tumors in the posterior pituitary are not associated with MEN-1. Other features of MEN-1 include adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors (usually of the foregut), meningiomas, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, and lipomas. The most common endocrine abnormalities in MEN-1 are multiglandular parathyroid tumors, leading to hyperparathyroidism. Hypercalcemia is often the first biochemical abnormality detected in MEN-1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are the second most common manifestation, and prolactinomas are the most common pituitary tumors in MEN-1.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: These are a common manifestation of MEN-1, often nonfunctioning or secreting pancreatic polypeptides. Functional NETs like gastrinomas and insulinomas are also seen.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors:
  • • Option C. Foregut carcinoid: Carcinoid tumors, typically of the foregut, can occur in patients with MEN-1.
  • • Option
  • • C. Foregut carcinoid:
  • • Option D. Parathyroid hyperplasia: Multiglandular parathyroid tumors are the most common endocrine abnormality in MEN-1, leading to hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Option
  • • D. Parathyroid hyperplasia:
  • • Educational objectives :
  • • Educational objectives :
  • • MEN-1 syndrome includes tumors of the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary, but not the posterior pituitary.

  • ➤ In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code , indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.
  • ➤ immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.
  • • Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:
  • • Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:
  • • Myogenic response Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)
  • • Myogenic response
  • • Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)
  • • (TGF)
  • • 1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE
  • • 1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE
  • • Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases, → stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole → Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells → The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole → So, the blood flow is decreased.
  • • →
  • • →
  • • →
  • • →
  • • 2. TGF
  • • 2. TGF
  • • The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. NO : Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.
  • • Option A. NO
  • • Option B. Noradrenaline : Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.
  • • Option B. Noradrenaline
  • • Option D. Adenosine : Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.
  • • Option D. Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of persistent fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold temperatures, and unexplained weight gain over the past year. He also reports experiencing dry skin, muscle cramps, and constipation. On physical examination, the physician notes coarse, dry skin, mild swelling around the eyes, and a slightly enlarged but non-tender thyroid gland. Laboratory results reveal an elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and a low free thyroxine (T4) level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's constellation of symptoms of fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, dry skin, constipation, and muscle cramps is highly suggestive of hypothyroidism. The elevated TSH level and low free T4 level confirm this diagnosis. Furthermore, the presence of a slightly enlarged thyroid gland (goiter) points toward Hashimoto's thyroiditis, an autoimmune condition that is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to its gradual destruction and decreased thyroid hormone production.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pituitary insufficiency: This would lead to central hypothyroidism, characterized by low or inappropriately normal TSH levels, which is not consistent with this patient's elevated TSH.
  • • Option B. Pituitary insufficiency:
  • • Option C. Euthyroid sick syndrome: This condition is typically seen in critically ill patients and is characterized by abnormal thyroid function tests without true thyroid dysfunction. It is not associated with the classic hypothyroid symptoms this patient is experiencing.
  • • Option C. Euthyroid sick syndrome:
  • • Option D. Iodine deficiency goiter: While iodine deficiency can cause hypothyroidism and goiter, it is less common in developed countries where iodine intake is generally sufficient.
  • • Option D. Iodine deficiency goiter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It presents with elevated TSH, low T4, and a constellation of symptoms related to hypothyroidism. Early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for proper management.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)

  • ➤ Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: All are long-term reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years. Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years. Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs):
  • • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • • Implants:
  • • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.
  • • Injectable contraceptives:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.
  • • Option A. Progestin injection:
  • • Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.
  • • Option B. Progestin implants:
  • • Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.
  • • Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition pg 491-492,479,
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: The acronym FAST refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma

options.label: B
options.text: Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.correct_answer: B. Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive , rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen. It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes . The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries. The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch. The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury. The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.
  • ➤ FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive , rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen.
  • ➤ Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive
  • ➤ It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes .
  • ➤ thoracoabdominal injuries
  • ➤ 2-4 minutes
  • ➤ The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • ➤ The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch.
  • ➤ The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • ➤ The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.
  • ➤ eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a hard painless testicular swelling. There were no inguinal, intra-abdominal or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan. The blood workup showed AFP levels of > 3000. USG shows uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis. The next line of management is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) High inguinal orchidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given features that point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in stage I of the tumor. In a case of painless swelling of the testis, a testicular tumor should be suspected. The associated rise in AFP level points toward a diagnosis of NSGCT although tissue diagnosis is required to confirm the nature of the tumor. But tissue diagnosis is not a prerequisite for treatment, and hence, based on the available evidence a high inguinal orchidectomy is done in this case. Further treatment is followed up based on the findings of the excisional biopsy.
  • ➤ NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy. Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy. For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.
  • ➤ NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy.
  • ➤ Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy.
  • ➤ For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.correct_answer: D. By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • PTH increases calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing the kidneys' excretion of calcium, effectively increasing plasma calcium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. By increasing osteoclast activity: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclasts indirectly, leading to increased bone resorption, which releases calcium into the bloodstream.
  • • Option A.
  • • By increasing osteoclast activity:
  • • Option B. By increasing osteoblastic activity: While PTH does stimulate osteoblasts, this action is primarily to produce RANKL, a cytokine that activates osteoclasts, not to build new bone.
  • • Option B.
  • • By increasing osteoblastic activity:
  • • Option C. By decreasing renal excretion: PTH reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys, increasing reabsorption of calcium in the renal tubules, contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • • Option C.
  • • By decreasing renal excretion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases plasma calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing renal excretion of calcium.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

  • ➤ B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)
  • ➤ E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma
  • ➤ N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.
  • ➤ The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.
  • ➤ Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone
  • ➤ 7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy
  • ➤ 10 to 12: Mastectomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided flank pain, nausea, and fever for two days. He has a history of recurrent kidney stones and frequent urinary tract infections. Physical exam reveals tenderness over the left costovertebral angle. Laboratory findings show an elevated white blood cell count, and urinalysis reveals significant hematuria and pyuria. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen demonstrates a large, complex stone (>4 cm) occupying the left renal pelvis and extending into the calyces. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Conservative management with hydration and antibiotics

questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • PCNL is the gold standard for treating large or complex renal stones, especially those larger than 2 cm or staghorn calculi, as seen in this case. It involves creating a small incision in the back to access the kidney directly, allowing for effective stone fragmentation and removal. This approach minimizes complications and offers a high stone-free rate.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Conservative management: While hydration and antibiotics are important for managing associated infection and pain, they are not sufficient for large, complex stones like this one. Definitive stone removal is necessary to prevent complications.
  • • Option B. Conservative management:
  • • Option C. Open surgical nephrolithotomy: This invasive approach is rarely used as a first-line treatment due to its associated morbidity and longer recovery time. PCNL is less invasive and equally effective for large stones.
  • • Option C. Open surgical nephrolithotomy:
  • • Option D. Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS): This is more suitable for smaller stones or those in less complex locations within the kidney. It may not be effective for managing large staghorn calculi due to limited access and the inability to handle a large stone burden.
  • • Option D. Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PCNL is the preferred management for large or complex renal stones, such as staghorn calculi. It allows for direct access to the kidney, facilitates effective removal of large stone burdens, and significantly reduces the risk of complications associated with untreated stones.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.correct_answer: D. Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT. The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible. FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.
  • ➤ Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  • ➤ The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  • ➤ FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Reduction en masse

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cecum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • ➤ Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • ➤ Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.text: A patient was treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks. What is the main concern while considering his discharge from the hospital?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.  Suicidal risk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main concern when discharging a patient treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is the risk of suicide. This requires ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support to manage their mental health effectively after discharge.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the organism they are used for? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal . Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole. Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole ) Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine . Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin. Nitazoxanide : DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal . Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole. Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • ➤ Praziquantal
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole. Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole.
  • ➤ Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • ➤ Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole ) Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine . Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • ➤ Mebendazole
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine . Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine .
  • ➤ Diethylcarbamazine
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • ➤ Nitazoxanide : DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)
  • ➤ Nitazoxanide
